summary.value: We conducted a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials to promote health behavior change based on self-determination theory (SDT). The review aimed to (a) quantify the impact of SDT interventions on health behaviors, (b) test mediation by theoretically specified variables (autonomous motivation and perceived competence), and (c) identify moderators of intervention effectiveness. The sample-weighted average effect size for SDT interventions was d+ = .23, and there were significant effects for physical activity, sedentary behavior, diet, alcohol consumption, and smoking cessation (.16 ≥ d+ ≥ .29).

attributes.title: Data from: Quantile Graphs for EEG-Based Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease
attributes.description: The database was designed jointly by Dr. Dennis Duke and other researchers at Florida State University and it was recorded from the 19 scalp loci of the international 10-20 system using a Biologic Systems Brain Atlas III Plus workstation. Sets A and B represent the control group and consist of 24 healthy elderly, all being negative for any neurological or psychiatric disorder. Sets C and D consist of 24 probable AD patients diagnosed through the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association (NINCDS-ADRDA), and Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)-III-R criteria.

attributes.title: When and Why Choices for Others Diverge from Consumers' Own salient Goals

q1.value: Study with Control Condition Going Green

q4.value: This study will manipulate a personal goal of living an environmentally friendly lifestyle vs. control condition (no goal activated). Participants will imagine a scenario in which they are either choosing for themselves or for another person and will make a selection between an environmentally friendly activity (nature hike) and a neutral option (chocolate-making workshop). We will examine how choices for the self differ from those for another person. We predict that activating an environmental goal will increase choice of an environmentally friendly activity for the self, but it will decrease choice of environmentally friendly activity for another person.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: It is a 2x2 between subjects study with binary choice of goal-consistent versus neutral option as DV. Participants will be randomly assigned to either environmental goal condition or control condition. Participants in the environmental goal condition will list 5 reasons why living an environmentally friendly lifestyle is personally important to them. Participants in the control condition will list 5 words that begin with letter t. A series of questionnaires (described later) will be completed between goal priming and choice task. After that participants will be randomly assigned to either choice for self or choice for other condition. In the choice for self condition participants will imagine making a choice for themselves between a nature hike and a chocolate-making workshop. Participants in the choice for other condition will imagine choosing between a nature hike and a chocolate making workshop as an activity to give to a friend as a gift. manipulation check and demographics will follow.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I will recruit approximately 680 participants through MTurk. I will set criteria to a US sample with 95% or higher HIT approval rating. Each participant will be paid $0.50 for participating.

q13.value: approximately 680 . This study uses a conservative design: active goal versus control condition. and choice options are goal-consistent vs. neutral. We feel that a larger sample size (approx 170 per cell) is necessary to demonstrate the effects.

question.value:
Reactance (Hong and Faedda, 1996); Self-construal (Singelis, 1994); Need for uniqueness (Tian, Bearden, & Hunter, 2001); abbreviated Scheier & Carver's (2013) self consciousness scale: I care a lot about how I present myself to others, I am constantly thinking about my reasons for doing things, I sometimes step back (in my mind) in order to examine myself from a distance, and I am concerned about what other people think of me. Two additional questions will be asked: When I decide what to do I think about whether or not other people will interpret it as "being selfish," and When I decide what to do I think about whether or not other people will interpret it as "being lazy." all questions will utilize a 7-point scale anchored by 1=Strongly disagree 7 = Strongly agree.

DV: binary choice between a goal-consistent option--nature hike session and a neutral option--chocolate-making workshop

A manipulation check for relevance of options to the environmental goal: To what extent does each of the following activities help a person to make progress toward a goal to live an environmentally friendly lifestyle? A nature-hike session and A chocolate-making workshop; 1= Not at all, 7 = Very much so.

Repeated measures ANOVA with choice optin as within-subjects factor will be used to analyze the manipulation check.
Logistic regression will be used to analyze the DV. First, we will run a logistic regression with choice as DV and Goal, Recipient and interaction as predictors. Then we will rerun this regression with our measured control variables (reactance, self-construal, need for uniqueness, self-consciousness and concerns about laziness and selfishness perceptions) as covariates. We will also analyze meticulously whether our control variables influence choice using separate logistic regressions.

q3.value: Magical beliefs are strongly guided by intuition, and women are more likely to report magical beliefs than men. We propose that women’s stronger reliance on intuition helps to explain why they report higher magical beliefs than men. This experiment will examine if enhancing reliance on intuition increases men's magical beliefs, thereby attenuating gender differences in magical beliefs expected to emerge in the control condition.

q4.value:
In the control condition, women will report higher magical beliefs than men. 

In the intuition manipulation condition, men will report higher magical beliefs than in the control condition. Here we are referring to the initial ratings in the intuition condition (not the second administration of items that will be untimed). 

We have no predictions about women's change in magical beliefs in the control vs. intuition manipulation condition. It is possible that the intuition manipulation may also heighten women's magical beliefs (vs. control condition). However, to the extent that women are already relying on intuition when making ratings in the control condition, magical beliefs might not differ by condition for women.  

We have no specific predictions regarding how timed vs. untimed (i.e., initial vs. second administration) ratings will change within the intuition condition. According to theoretical views on this topic, rapid, intuitive ratings would lead to higher magical beliefs than untimed, reflective ratings. However, we think it is possible that participants might stick with their initial (intuitive) ratings when asked to rate items after reflection and, hence, we have no specific predictions for within-participant changes but plan to examine these for possible differences.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to a control condition or to an intuition manipulation condition and then will rate their magical beliefs. The control condition will make standard ratings without special instructions. In the intuition manipulation condition, participants will be instructed to go with their initial, intuitive response and they will be given a time limit to respond to each item (5 seconds). They will also be asked to memorize a pattern of dots while responding, as an additional cognitive load manipulation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. Any adult over the age of 18 who is signed up on Mechanical Turk in the United States may participate.  Payment is $0.20 for completion.  We are recruiting participants with at least a 95% hit approval rate in an effort to reduce poor quality data. We will exclude participants with duplicate IP addresses. This study will launch in January 2020.

q13.value: 350 participants (175 per condition) will be recruited to complete this study.

q14.value: We are running as many participants as our budget will permit to reach this sample size. We also strive to have a sample size comparable to the studies we have already conducted on this topic.

q15.value: If the condition sample sizes are far below 175 and unbalanced upon the termination of initial data collection, additional participants will be recruited to ensure the sample sizes are at least 175 per condition.

question.value: We are manipulating the extent to which people make judgments based on their intuition. In the control condition, participants will make standard ratings. In the intuition induction condition, participants will be told to rely on their initial intuitions when making judgments, they will be given 5 seconds per rating, and they will be asked to memorize a pattern of dots while making each rating (as a cognitive load manipulation). Afterwards, they will make the same ratings again without time restrictions or the memorization task. These manipulations are adapted from prior research (Bago & De Neys, 2017; Bago, Rand, & Pennycook, 2019).

Magical beliefs (6 items; used in our previous research on this topic)
Faith in Intuition (from Rational Experiential Inventory, Pacini & Epstein, 1999)

After inspecting the alpha scale reliability and dropping items with low item-total correlations, 
an aggregate magical beliefs variable will be formed with the mean of all items.

We will use a two-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) to examine the main effects of condition and participant gender, as well as whether there is an interaction between them, in predicting magical beliefs. 

Because the key research questions concern gender differences within the control condition and how men will alter magical beliefs between conditions, we will also use planned contrasts to test the following specific differences of interest (with magical beliefs as dependent variables): 
Women compared to men in the control condition.
Men in the control condition compared to men in the intuition condition. 

A repeated-measures GLM with post-hoc bonferroni comparisons will be used to examine whether timed vs. untimed ratings of magical beliefs (within-subjects factor) differed in the intuition condition or by participant gender (between-subjects factor). Untimed ratings in the intuition condition will also be compared to control condition ratings.

q21.value: We will be assessing p-values below .05 using two-tailed tests.

q22.value:
Prior to analyses, participants with duplicate IP addresses and worker IDs will be deleted (retaining only the first participant to complete the study from the IP address/worker ID specified). 

In the experimental condition, participants will have 5 seconds to respond to each of their six initial magical belief ratings. If participants do not respond to at least four out of these six items, they will be excluded from analyses. Participants in the experimental condition are also doing a cognitive load memory task while rating items. If participants respond incorrectly to four or more of the six memory questions, they will be excluded from analyses. 

Due to concerns about inattentive responding and non-human (computerized) responses on Mechanical Turk, we are including an instructional attention check item around the end of the study.  If participants respond incorrectly to it, they will be excluded from analyses. However, if over 15% of the sample fails this instructional attention check, we will retain the full sample and not use it for exclusions.

q24.value:
We will also analyze the effects of demographic variables beyond gender (age, education, income). 

Faith in intuition and religiosity will be measured for exploratory purposes and analyses will probe how they affected the pattern of results. 

Participants will be asked whether they wrote down any answers on the memory task or if their internet speed interfered with their performance on the task. Exploratory analyses may probe if these issues affected the pattern of results.

q25.value:
The predictions for these studies are based on some of our prior research, where we documented gender differences in magical beliefs (i.e., women higher than men) and showed that reliance on intuition helped to account for women's higher magical beliefs. 

Because the control condition is expected to take approximately half the time of the experimental condition to finish the study, we are adding addition measures for an unrelated study to the end of the study in the control condition.

attributes.title: Impact of market mindset on interpersonal trust

q1.value: The impact of market mindset on interpersonal trust: Investigation of the mechanism behind the divergent effects of market mindset on trust (part 1b)

q2.value: Anna Kuzminska, Agata Gasiorowska, Tomasz Zaleskiewicz

q3.value:
Trust is essential for smooth functioning of most types of human relations (e.g., Akerlof, 1970; Reis, Clark, & Holmes, 2004), including communal and exchange/market-pricing relationships (Clark & Mills, 1993; Fiske, 1992). Our previous research showed that market mindset might reduce communal trust experienced in the communal-sharing model of relationships, but foster transactional trust associated with the market-pricing model of relationships and one's desire to maximize own outcomes. This experiment is aimed at investigating the mechanism behind these divergent effects of market mindset on trust. 

Although in both market and communal contexts trust involves vulnerability and uncertainty on the part of trustors (e.g. Coleman, 1990, Deutsch, 1962, Yamagishi, 1998), different qualities of the other person might be crucial when deciding whether to trust the other person. Communal relationships are based on concern for others and their needs (Clark & Mills, 1993). Helping is non-contingent and the main values include generosity, altruism, and community. A dimension of social judgment that exemplifies these traits is communion (Abele & Wojciszke, 2007). Those high in communion care for the interests of others, are benevolent, and empathetic. On the other hand, in the context of market relationships our focus is on receiving at least a comparable return of our input and the most commonly embraced values are agency, efficacy, and self-sufficiency (Clark & Mills, 1993). As a result, other person’s traits that matter in this context are their competence (including an ability to provide us with the direct returns we desire), understanding of the market rules, as well as their self-interest embedded in the positive outcome of this interaction. Agency is a dimension underlying social judgment that encompasses these characteristics (e.g. Abele & Wojciszke, 2007). A person judged to be agentic is focused on their own goals, decisive, and efficient. Indeed, previous research showed that agency traits are selected more frequently in exchange relationships than in communal relationships (Abele & Brack, 2013). 

In the current study, we aim at investigating whether the level of trust expressed in the Trust Game is affected by the level of communion and agency of the trustee, and whether this effect is moderated by the construal of the social situation as market exchange or communal sharing. Consistent with the results of the previous studies (e.g. Liberman, Samuels, & Ross, 2004), we expect that a stimulus situation can be framed in different ways, affecting its interpretation. Consequently, when Trust Game is introduced to the participants as the Wall Street Task it should evoke a market exchange context, whereas when Trust Game is named the Community Task it should induce a communal context. In our study, we will also manipulate trustee's level of communion and agency. We expect that trusting behavior (operationalized as a sum transferred to the trustee in the Trust Game) will more strongly depend on trustee's level of agency when the game framing indicates the market exchange context (Wall Street Task) rather than the communal context (Community Task). On the other hand, trust will more strongly depend on trustee's level of communion when the game framing indicates a communal context, as compared to market context.

q4.value: We hypothesize that the relationship between trust expressed in the Trust Game and two dimensions underlying social judgments, agency and communion, will be different depending on whether the Trust Game framing indicates market exchange (Wall Street Task) or communal (Community Task) mode of relationship. In other words, we expect that the level of trustee’s agency and communion (high vs. low) will interact with the Trust Game framing (Wall Street vs. Community Task) in predicting the amount of money sent to the trustee in the Trust Game. More precisely, we expect that the effect of agency manipulation on the amount transferred in the Trust game will be stronger when the game is framed as Wall Street Task rather than Community Task  (H1), while the effect of communion manipulation on this amount sent will be stronger when the game is framed as Community Task rather than Wall Street Task (H2).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: This will be an internet-based study, with no direct interaction between experimenters and study subjects. The random assignment to experimental groups will be performed automatically.

question.value: Our study will follow a between-subject, 2 (Game Framing: Wall Street Task vs. Community Task) x 2 (Trustee's Agency: Low vs. High) x 2(Trustee's Communion: Low vs. High) design.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the eight experimental conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected using the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform from a sample of the US participants. Participants will be rewarded $0.65 for their time and effort. Additionally, each participant will play the Trust Game with monetary rewards. This additional reward will depend on the decisions made in the game and could vary between $0.15 and $1.

q13.value: We will aim at recruiting a total of 480 participants (60 per experimental condition).

q14.value: We computed the effect size for game framing manipulation in the game based on the Liberman, Samuels, and Ross (2004) study 1. Their results indicated a large effect of game framing on participants’ behavior in that game (Cohen's d = 0.91). A priori power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) revealed that given an alpha of .05 and a conventionally assumed power of .80, a sample of 20 participants per condition in between-condition design would be required to detect the effect of a similar size. Because in our study we used an additional manipulation of game partner's level of agency and communion, for which the effect size is unknown, and we planned to investigate not only the difference in means between conditions, but also the interaction effects, we aimed to triple this number and recruit 60 participants to each experimental condition in the study.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated after reaching the desired sample size (before potential exclusions are made).

question.value:
Game framing type manipulation (market vs. communal framing):
The Trust Game will be introduced to the participants as either WALL STREET TASK or COMMUNITY TASK. Both the instructions to the game as well as the captions throughout the game will be changed accordingly, depending on the condition. The exact wording of the main instructions can be seen below:

RULES OF THE WALL STREET / COMMUNITY TASK
Please read this description carefully in order to understand the rules of the task. 
In the WALL STREET/COMMUNITY TASK, you can be assigned the role of Person A or Person B.
1. At the beginning of the WALL STREET/COMMUNITY TASK Person A will be endowed with $1. Person B will not be endowed with any money.
2. Person A can keep the entire endowment for him/herself or give any amount of it to Person B.
3. The amount sent by Person A will be automatically tripled. Each transferred cent turns into three cents on the account of Person B. The amount that Person A leaves for him/herself remains unchanged.
4. Person B may send any amount of the received money back to Person A. The amount sent back by Person B will no longer be multiplied.
4. The final amount accumulated by each person will be paid out once the study is completed.

Manipulation of Trustee's Agency and Communion 
To manipulate trustee’s agency and communion, we will show participants trustee's responses to ten items of the agency and communion questionnaire (measure by Abele, Hauke, Peters, Louvet, Szymkow, & Duan, 2016). The scale’s title will not be used in the instructions. Abele et al. (2016) differentiated Agency into assertiveness (AA) and competence (AC) and Communion into warmth (CW) and morality (CM). In this study we decided to only use the Warmth and Competence subscales of the questionnaire, because they better represent the definitional characteristics of communal and exchange relationships (Clark & Mills, 2011; Fiske, 1992). The AC scale is composed of the following items: capable, efficient, intelligent, clever, and competent. The CW scale consists of the following items: affectionate, empathetic, friendly, caring, warm in relations with others. Depending on the experimental condition, the trustee's responses will be presented as being: 1) high in the agency traits and high in the communion traits, 2) high in the agency traits and low in the communion traits, 3) low in both agency and communion traits, 4) low in agency traits and high in communion traits. Participants will be familiarized with the scale, by filling it in themselves in the beginning of the study.

The outcome variable of interest is the amount of money transferred to the second person in the Trust Game. Using $0.10 increments, participants will be asked to decide how much of the initial $1 endowment they wish to allocate to the second person in the game.
N/A

Main variables:

Experimental manipulations:
1) Game framing (market vs. communal)
2) Trustee's level of agency (high vs. low)
3) Trustee's level of communion (high vs. low)

Measured variables: the amount of money transferred to the second person in the Trust Game.

 
Statistical techniques:
We will perform a 2(game framing: Wall Street Task vs. Community Task) x 2(trustee's agency: Low vs. High) x 2(trustee's communion: Low vs. High) ANOVA. Then, in planned contrasts, we will decompose the three-way interaction and test examine the two-way interactions between agency and game framing and between communion and effect framing. In terms of simple effects, we will compare (1) the effect size for agency when game is framed as Wall Street Task and as Community Task, and (2) effect size for communion when game is framed as Wall Street Task and as Community Task.

q21.value: We will be using a two tailed test in our analyses, with alpha of 0.05 used as the cutoff for significance

q22.value: We will exclude participants who fail to provide a valid response to the questions aimed at checking their understanding of Trust Game rules: (1) If Person A sends the whole amount (i.e. $1) to Person B, how much money will Person B receive? and (2) If Person B sends half of that received amount back to Person A, how much money will both of them have in the end of the WALL STREET / COMMUNITY TASK?

registration_responses.q1: The impact of market mindset on interpersonal trust: Investigation of the mechanism behind the divergent effects of market mindset on trust (part 1b)
registration_responses.q2: Anna Kuzminska, Agata Gasiorowska, Tomasz Zaleskiewicz
registration_responses.q3:
Trust is essential for smooth functioning of most types of human relations (e.g., Akerlof, 1970; Reis, Clark, & Holmes, 2004), including communal and exchange/market-pricing relationships (Clark & Mills, 1993; Fiske, 1992). Our previous research showed that market mindset might reduce communal trust experienced in the communal-sharing model of relationships, but foster transactional trust associated with the market-pricing model of relationships and one's desire to maximize own outcomes. This experiment is aimed at investigating the mechanism behind these divergent effects of market mindset on trust. 

Although in both market and communal contexts trust involves vulnerability and uncertainty on the part of trustors (e.g. Coleman, 1990, Deutsch, 1962, Yamagishi, 1998), different qualities of the other person might be crucial when deciding whether to trust the other person. Communal relationships are based on concern for others and their needs (Clark & Mills, 1993). Helping is non-contingent and the main values include generosity, altruism, and community. A dimension of social judgment that exemplifies these traits is communion (Abele & Wojciszke, 2007). Those high in communion care for the interests of others, are benevolent, and empathetic. On the other hand, in the context of market relationships our focus is on receiving at least a comparable return of our input and the most commonly embraced values are agency, efficacy, and self-sufficiency (Clark & Mills, 1993). As a result, other person’s traits that matter in this context are their competence (including an ability to provide us with the direct returns we desire), understanding of the market rules, as well as their self-interest embedded in the positive outcome of this interaction. Agency is a dimension underlying social judgment that encompasses these characteristics (e.g. Abele & Wojciszke, 2007). A person judged to be agentic is focused on their own goals, decisive, and efficient. Indeed, previous research showed that agency traits are selected more frequently in exchange relationships than in communal relationships (Abele & Brack, 2013). 

In the current study, we aim at investigating whether the level of trust expressed in the Trust Game is affected by the level of communion and agency of the trustee, and whether this effect is moderated by the construal of the social situation as market exchange or communal sharing. Consistent with the results of the previous studies (e.g. Liberman, Samuels, & Ross, 2004), we expect that a stimulus situation can be framed in different ways, affecting its interpretation. Consequently, when Trust Game is introduced to the participants as the Wall Street Task it should evoke a market exchange context, whereas when Trust Game is named the Community Task it should induce a communal context. In our study, we will also manipulate trustee's level of communion and agency. We expect that trusting behavior (operationalized as a sum transferred to the trustee in the Trust Game) will more strongly depend on trustee's level of agency when the game framing indicates the market exchange context (Wall Street Task) rather than the communal context (Community Task). On the other hand, trust will more strongly depend on trustee's level of communion when the game framing indicates a communal context, as compared to market context.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that the relationship between trust expressed in the Trust Game and two dimensions underlying social judgments, agency and communion, will be different depending on whether the Trust Game framing indicates market exchange (Wall Street Task) or communal (Community Task) mode of relationship. In other words, we expect that the level of trustee’s agency and communion (high vs. low) will interact with the Trust Game framing (Wall Street vs. Community Task) in predicting the amount of money sent to the trustee in the Trust Game. More precisely, we expect that the effect of agency manipulation on the amount transferred in the Trust game will be stronger when the game is framed as Wall Street Task rather than Community Task  (H1), while the effect of communion manipulation on this amount sent will be stronger when the game is framed as Community Task rather than Wall Street Task (H2).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q7: This will be an internet-based study, with no direct interaction between experimenters and study subjects. The random assignment to experimental groups will be performed automatically.
registration_responses.q9: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the eight experimental conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will aim at recruiting a total of 480 participants (60 per experimental condition).
registration_responses.q14: We computed the effect size for game framing manipulation in the game based on the Liberman, Samuels, and Ross (2004) study 1. Their results indicated a large effect of game framing on participants’ behavior in that game (Cohen's d = 0.91). A priori power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) revealed that given an alpha of .05 and a conventionally assumed power of .80, a sample of 20 participants per condition in between-condition design would be required to detect the effect of a similar size. Because in our study we used an additional manipulation of game partner's level of agency and communion, for which the effect size is unknown, and we planned to investigate not only the difference in means between conditions, but also the interaction effects, we aimed to triple this number and recruit 60 participants to each experimental condition in the study.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be terminated after reaching the desired sample size (before potential exclusions are made).
registration_responses.q21: We will be using a two tailed test in our analyses, with alpha of 0.05 used as the cutoff for significance
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude participants who fail to provide a valid response to the questions aimed at checking their understanding of Trust Game rules: (1) If Person A sends the whole amount (i.e. $1) to Person B, how much money will Person B receive? and (2) If Person B sends half of that received amount back to Person A, how much money will both of them have in the end of the WALL STREET / COMMUNITY TASK?
registration_responses.q8.question: Our study will follow a between-subject, 2 (Game Framing: Wall Street Task vs. Community Task) x 2 (Trustee's Agency: Low vs. High) x 2(Trustee's Communion: Low vs. High) design.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data will be collected using the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform from a sample of the US participants. Participants will be rewarded $0.65 for their time and effort. Additionally, each participant will play the Trust Game with monetary rewards. This additional reward will depend on the decisions made in the game and could vary between $0.15 and $1.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Game framing type manipulation (market vs. communal framing):
The Trust Game will be introduced to the participants as either WALL STREET TASK or COMMUNITY TASK. Both the instructions to the game as well as the captions throughout the game will be changed accordingly, depending on the condition. The exact wording of the main instructions can be seen below:

RULES OF THE WALL STREET / COMMUNITY TASK
Please read this description carefully in order to understand the rules of the task. 
In the WALL STREET/COMMUNITY TASK, you can be assigned the role of Person A or Person B.
1. At the beginning of the WALL STREET/COMMUNITY TASK Person A will be endowed with $1. Person B will not be endowed with any money.
2. Person A can keep the entire endowment for him/herself or give any amount of it to Person B.
3. The amount sent by Person A will be automatically tripled. Each transferred cent turns into three cents on the account of Person B. The amount that Person A leaves for him/herself remains unchanged.
4. Person B may send any amount of the received money back to Person A. The amount sent back by Person B will no longer be multiplied.
4. The final amount accumulated by each person will be paid out once the study is completed.

Manipulation of Trustee's Agency and Communion 
To manipulate trustee’s agency and communion, we will show participants trustee's responses to ten items of the agency and communion questionnaire (measure by Abele, Hauke, Peters, Louvet, Szymkow, & Duan, 2016). The scale’s title will not be used in the instructions. Abele et al. (2016) differentiated Agency into assertiveness (AA) and competence (AC) and Communion into warmth (CW) and morality (CM). In this study we decided to only use the Warmth and Competence subscales of the questionnaire, because they better represent the definitional characteristics of communal and exchange relationships (Clark & Mills, 2011; Fiske, 1992). The AC scale is composed of the following items: capable, efficient, intelligent, clever, and competent. The CW scale consists of the following items: affectionate, empathetic, friendly, caring, warm in relations with others. Depending on the experimental condition, the trustee's responses will be presented as being: 1) high in the agency traits and high in the communion traits, 2) high in the agency traits and low in the communion traits, 3) low in both agency and communion traits, 4) low in agency traits and high in communion traits. Participants will be familiarized with the scale, by filling it in themselves in the beginning of the study.
registration_responses.q17.question: The outcome variable of interest is the amount of money transferred to the second person in the Trust Game. Using $0.10 increments, participants will be asked to decide how much of the initial $1 endowment they wish to allocate to the second person in the game.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
Main variables:

Experimental manipulations:
1) Game framing (market vs. communal)
2) Trustee's level of agency (high vs. low)
3) Trustee's level of communion (high vs. low)

Measured variables: the amount of money transferred to the second person in the Trust Game.

 
Statistical techniques:
We will perform a 2(game framing: Wall Street Task vs. Community Task) x 2(trustee's agency: Low vs. High) x 2(trustee's communion: Low vs. High) ANOVA. Then, in planned contrasts, we will decompose the three-way interaction and test examine the two-way interactions between agency and game framing and between communion and effect framing. In terms of simple effects, we will compare (1) the effect size for agency when game is framed as Wall Street Task and as Community Task, and (2) effect size for communion when game is framed as Wall Street Task and as Community Task.

q1.value: Might the ability to estimate an advisor's idiosyncratic confidence scale increase advice taking?

q3.value: Observations from evolutionary models (https://github.com/oxacclab/EvoEgoBias) show that egocentric discounting is a successful strategy in environments where advisors cannot be clear on how advisors' expressed confidence relates to their actual confidence. We reason that human participants may show a sensitivity to these contextual factors underlying advice-taking and respond to them in a rational manner.

q4.value: We hypothesised that participants would place greater weight on the advice of a consistent advisor versus one of a group of advisors, presumably because they are able to learn about the calibration of the individual advisor while they cannot do likewise for the population of advisors.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A within-subjects design in which participants in a judge-advisor system make initial estimates, receive advice, and provide final decisions. They complete two conditions: in one the advice they received was always labeled as coming from a consistent individual, while in the other the advice was labeled as coming from a different advisor each time.

Full study code can be found on the project github repository (https://github.com/oxacclab/ExploringSocialMetacognition/).

q9.value: The order of conditions (single advisor first or mass advisors first) is randomly assigned using block-randomisation for blocks of 20 participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Human participants will be recruited from the Prolific platform. Participants are paid £3.50 for participation, approximately £10/hour. Participants are only offered the study if they have a high performance on the platform (>=95% approval) and have not participated in similar studies from our lab before. Data collection is anticipated to last a few hours, but may be done in batches over a few days if required (see sample size justification below).

q13.value:
The sample size will be determined dynamically by using Bayes Factors for the key outcome (difference between weight on advice for advisors labelled 'honest' vs advisors labelled 'deceptive' for advice judged as 'honest' by participants). Data will be collected starting with 20 participants and increasing in batches of 10 participants until either the bayes factor for the key outcome is below 1/3rd, the bayes factor is above 3, or 60 participants have been recruited. 

The analysis script will be run periodically to ensure its suitability for the data and to check that the task works as expected. If major technical problems are encountered, collected data will be discarded, the problems fixed, and data collection restarted. For minor problems (e.g. with the analysis script rather than experimental task), data collected prior to the fix will be retained.

q14.value: We have very little idea how strong the manipulation in the experiment will be, and how great the magnitude of a successful manipulation could be. As such there is no a priori rationale for the sample size except the financial constraint on the upper bound.

question.value: Advisor: consistent individual vs. one of a group

Initial estimate: participants provide an initial estimate of the date of the event in question
Final estimate: participants provide a final estimate of the date of the event in question

Influence is the extent to which a participant's confidence moves in the expected direction as a function of the advice (increasing when agreed with, decreasing when disagreed with). 
The participant's initial estimate is coded as a positive value representing the participant's confidence. The advice is then coded as a positive (agreement) or negative (disagreement) value representing the advisor's confidence. 
Formula:
Influence|agreement = final decision - intial estimate
Influence|disagreement = -(final decision - initial estimate)

Bayesian T-tests are used to test the hypothesis.
Analysis script and custom dependencies are in the Analysis subcomponent (https://osf.io/7ctvf/).

q21.value: Bayes factor < 1/3 will be taken as evidence in favour of the null hypothesis, > 3 as evidence in favour of the alternative hypothesis.

q22.value:
Participants can be excluded for a variety of reasons:
* failing attention checks
* having too few trials after individual trials are removed (response time > 1minute)
* altering their response on fewer than 10% of trials
* attempting to provide multiple responses

q23.value: Participants with too much missing data should be excluded (above), but in the event that data make the analysis script fail, those data will be removed from analysis.

q24.value: No exploratory analyses are registered at this stage.

q14.value: We have very little idea how strong the manipulation in the experiment will be, and how great the magnitude of a successful manipulation could be. As such there is no a priori rationale for the sample size except the financial constraint on the upper bound.

question.value: Advisor: consistent individual vs. one of a group

Initial estimate: participants provide an initial estimate of the date of the event in question
Final estimate: participants provide a final estimate of the date of the event in question

Influence is the extent to which a participant's confidence moves in the expected direction as a function of the advice (increasing when agreed with, decreasing when disagreed with). 
The participant's initial estimate is coded as a positive value representing the participant's confidence. The advice is then coded as a positive (agreement) or negative (disagreement) value representing the advisor's confidence. 
Formula:
Influence|agreement = final decision - intial estimate
Influence|disagreement = -(final decision - initial estimate)

Bayesian T-tests are used to test the hypothesis.
Analysis script and custom dependencies are in the Analysis subcomponent (https://osf.io/7ctvf/).

q21.value: Bayes factor < 1/3 will be taken as evidence in favour of the null hypothesis, > 3 as evidence in favour of the alternative hypothesis.

q22.value:
Participants can be excluded for a variety of reasons:
* failing attention checks
* having too few trials after individual trials are removed (response time > 1minute)
* altering their response on fewer than 10% of trials
* attempting to provide multiple responses

q23.value: Participants with too much missing data should be excluded (above), but in the event that data make the analysis script fail, those data will be removed from analysis.

q24.value: No exploratory analyses are registered at this stage.

registration_responses.q1: Might the ability to estimate an advisor's idiosyncratic confidence scale increase advice taking?
registration_responses.q3: Observations from evolutionary models (https://github.com/oxacclab/EvoEgoBias) show that egocentric discounting is a successful strategy in environments where advisors cannot be clear on how advisors' expressed confidence relates to their actual confidence. We reason that human participants may show a sensitivity to these contextual factors underlying advice-taking and respond to them in a rational manner.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesised that participants would place greater weight on the advice of a consistent advisor versus one of a group of advisors, presumably because they are able to learn about the calibration of the individual advisor while they cannot do likewise for the population of advisors.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: The order of conditions (single advisor first or mass advisors first) is randomly assigned using block-randomisation for blocks of 20 participants.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
The sample size will be determined dynamically by using Bayes Factors for the key outcome (difference between weight on advice for advisors labelled 'honest' vs advisors labelled 'deceptive' for advice judged as 'honest' by participants). Data will be collected starting with 20 participants and increasing in batches of 10 participants until either the bayes factor for the key outcome is below 1/3rd, the bayes factor is above 3, or 60 participants have been recruited. 

The analysis script will be run periodically to ensure its suitability for the data and to check that the task works as expected. If major technical problems are encountered, collected data will be discarded, the problems fixed, and data collection restarted. For minor problems (e.g. with the analysis script rather than experimental task), data collected prior to the fix will be retained.

registration_responses.q8.question:
A within-subjects design in which participants in a judge-advisor system make initial estimates, receive advice, and provide final decisions. They complete two conditions: in one the advice they received was always labeled as coming from a consistent individual, while in the other the advice was labeled as coming from a different advisor each time.

Full study code can be found on the project github repository (https://github.com/oxacclab/ExploringSocialMetacognition/).
registration_responses.q12.question: Human participants will be recruited from the Prolific platform. Participants are paid £3.50 for participation, approximately £10/hour. Participants are only offered the study if they have a high performance on the platform (>=95% approval) and have not participated in similar studies from our lab before. Data collection is anticipated to last a few hours, but may be done in batches over a few days if required (see sample size justification below).

attributes.title: Test of a dynamic change in efficacy beliefs predicting a change in action intentions

summary.value:
1. No data have been collected for this study yet


2.	What's the main question being asked or hypothesis being tested in this study? 
This study will be a direct methodological replication of a previous pre-registered project (osf.io/dh6gf), with the main aim being to test whether a within-person change in efficacy can in turn predict a within-person change in collective action intentions. The same procedure and materials will be used from the previous project (with one alteration, see Section 3). The justification for this replication are: 
•	To address a sampling error in the original study, in that due to a technical error, only 18 – 19 year olds were able to take part in the study. Whilst this does not negate the findings from the original study, we felt it was important to see if findings could be replicated with a wider age sample, with 18 years old being the lower limit, and no upper age limit. 
•	Exploratory analysis from the original study found significant effects for the relationship between efficacy as a mediator variable, and collective self-objectification (CSO) and empowering emotions as outcome variables. Therefore, we are adding these variables to the main analysis, and pre-registering the predicted significant pathways for this model. 
For both models, we will test two concurrent dynamic mediations; firstly, change between time one and time two for both the mediator and outcome variables, and secondly, change between time one and time three for both the mediator and outcome variables. We will also test a sequential dynamic mediation, with change between time one and time two for the mediator variable, and change between time one and time three for the outcome variables. 
Similarly to the previous project, for our first model we predict that those who see the empowering stimulus will display a greater change in efficacy beliefs between time one and time three compared to participants in the control condition. In turn they will show a greater change in willingness to take action between time one and time three (see red pathway in figure 1). We also predict that changes in efficacy and action intentions will be greater in those who see the empowering stimulus if levels of those variables are initially lower at time one (see blue pathways in figure 1). 
 

Figure 1. A model showing predicted direction of significant pathways for the first model. Small dotted lines are pathways fixed at ‘1’, as they set the measurement scale for latent variables, and/or are necessary for model identification purposes (Byrne 2009). Double-headed arrows indicate that two variables will be correlated. Coloured lines represent key pathways being tested. 


For our second model, we predict that those in the experimental condition will display a greater change in efficacy between time one and time three compared to participants in the control condition. In turn, they will show a greater change in CSO and empowering emotions between time one and time three (see red pathways in figure 2). We also predict that changes in efficacy beliefs, CSO and empowering emotions will be greater if levels of those variables are initially lower at time one (see blue pathways in figure 2).


Figure 2. A model showing predicted direction of significant pathways for the second model being tested. Small dotted lines are pathways fixed at ‘1’, as they set the measurement scale for latent variables, and/or are necessary for model identification purposes (Byrne 2009). Double-headed arrows indicate that two variables will be correlated. Coloured lines represent key pathways being tested. 




3.	Describe the key dependent variable(s) specifying how they will be measured. 

In conceptual terms, the key dependent variables are change in efficacy and change in action intentions, and for our second analysis, they are change in efficacy, CSO and empowering emotions. These will be operationalised by measuring key variables across three different time points using a self-report questionnaire. Change across time periods on a given measure will then be represented as a latent variable in order to assess associations between the manipulation and key variables. 
Efficacy will be measured on two different sub-scales; group efficacy and participative efficacy. Following findings from the original study, it was decided that political efficacy was not a dimension being affected by the video intervention, and will therefore not be included in this questionnaire. We also add two additional key variables, measuring CSO and empowerment emotions. The key variables and scales being used in the main analyses are: 
•	Group efficacy (4 items)
•	Participative efficacy (4 items)
•	Action intentions (8 items)
•	Empowerment emotions (8 items)
•	CSO (8 items)
Again, we will also measure legitimacy beliefs and a range of emotions towards the issue and the campaign (total of 29 emotion items).



4.	How many and which conditions will participants be assigned to? 

The procedure will be a direct replication of the previous project, with participants being randomly assigned to either the control condition or the experimental condition by the survey software. 


5.	Specify exactly which analyses you will conduct to examine the main question/hypothesis. 

Similarly to the previous project, a dynamic mediation analysis will be carried out using structural equation modelling in AMOS. Change in efficacy beliefs between time one and time two, and change in action intentions between time one and time three, will be the mediator and outcome variables respectively. See figure 1 for a diagram of the model that will be tested. For the second model, change in efficacy beliefs between time one and time three will be the mediator variable, with change in CSO and empowering emotions, both between time one and time three, will be the outcome variables. See figure 2 for a diagram of the model that will be tested.  


6.	Any secondary analyses? 

There will be no secondary analyses for this project. 






7.	How many observations will be collected or what will determine the sample size? No need to justify decision, but be precise about exactly how the number will be determined. 

We will aim to recruit 180 participants at all three time points using Prolific Academic, which is the maximum sample we can recruit given our budget and payment rate (£5 per participant). However, we will aim to recruit up to 200 participants at time 1 to allow for approximately 10% drop-out over the three time points. In terms of power analysis, the closest analogue in G*power is a repeated-between interaction in a mixed ANOVA. A sample size of 180 would provide just over 80% power to detect an effect size of approximately f = .04 or p = .02, which represent small-to-medium effects in a repeated-measures design, according to Bakeman (2005). 


8.	Anything else you would like to pre-register? (e.g., data exclusions, variables collected for exploratory purposes, unusual analyses planned?) 

For missing data we will use the expectation maximization (EM) method in SPSS. If participants have > 50% data missing or systematic missing data, they will be excluded from the analysis altogether.
